_decoded_content.title: sqlfluff does not work with adapter specific config expected env vars
_decoded_content.description:
I invite the team to throw in more context, but essentially adapter specific dbt and the profiles.yml do not work with sqlfluff without trying to mess around with `env_aliases` and "back into injecting the env vars". 

I propose a cleaner solution in using an explicit namespace that shadows the adapter specific namespace. If that is done, then you can use intuitive configuration in `meltano.yml` to configure sqlfluff. 

![image](/uploads/12f12920cb734bf4d58a478f4e2082e0/image.png)

![image](/uploads/58d33d8af1343a58be22008b021f325b/image.png)

_decoded_content.title: Add capability to send notifications on successful/failed executions
_decoded_content.description:
### Problem to solve
(Summarize the problem we are trying to solve in the form of we need to do [A], so that [B] can [C])

For simple Meltano deployments not relying on Airflow or other orchestrators, it'd be nice if Meltano was able to send notifications through one or more configurable channels (email, Slack, etc.).

### Target audience
(For whom are we doing this? Include a persona)

Users of Meltano that don't rely on orchestrators to run Meltano.

### Further details
(Include use cases, benefits, and/or goals)

- Failed extractions send an email to the on-call data engineer.
- Failed transformations send a push notification to the stakeholder for a dbt model.

### Proposal
(How are we going to solve the problem? Try to include the user journey)

There are tools out there like [apprise](https://github.com/caronc/apprise) that promise to make it easy to send notifications to arbitrary destinations.

We'd want to make it easy to add new notification destinations and different notification frameworks, so this is probably a good candidate to be a reference implementation of a third-party plugin (https://gitlab.com/meltano/meltano/-/issues/3038 and https://gitlab.com/meltano/meltano/-/issues/3080).

### What does success look like, and how can we measure that?
(Define both the success metrics and acceptance criteria. Note that success metrics indicate the desired business outcomes, while acceptance criteria indicate when the solution is working correctly. If there is no way to measure success, link to an issue that will implement a way to measure this)

Users can configure notifications to be sent to a number of destinations, based on success, failure, stage of the pipeline.

### Regression test
(Ensure the feature doesn't cause any regressions)
- [ ] Write adequate test cases and submit test results
- [ ] Test results should be reviewed by a person from the team

### Links / references

_Please note that this was taken from GitLab, to be changed accordingly_

_decoded_content.title: Editing files from file bundle plugin types looses access to future updates
_decoded_content.description:
The file bundle plugin type is used for generating boilerplate files needed to work with a particular plugin. This gives you the flexibility to adjust the files to suit your needs, and you can [disable the plugin's management the file](https://meltano.com/docs/plugins.html#how-to-use-12).

However, if you customize the file in question, you loose out on updated functionality from the plugin in the future. This makes it tough for being iterative with these plugins, as early adopters will have a harder time getting updates.

Some thoughts from Demo Day (2021-09-15) discussion:

- Meltano could show the diff between the old and new and let you choose how you want to incorporate those changes, if at all (@DouweM)
- Perhaps there's some way to separate plugin-managed parts from user-managed parts, a la `conf.d`. This will vary by file type unless we can come up with some generalized way to do it (@vischous)
- This is a common problem in the Wordpress community, they may have good solutions for this
- Maybe it's not that big of a problem, if you know enough to edit the file in question you are probably capable of maintaining the file yourself

_decoded_content.title: Connection Manager
_decoded_content.description:
## Change Log
**29/07/21** - Updated to include feedback up to [message](https://gitlab.com/meltano/meltano/-/issues/2873#note_637562612) by @vischous

## Description

As a user in the Meltano ecosystem I would like to manage connections and remote application/system configuration directly in Meltano. Today, before I can connect a Tap or Target, there are actions I must take to configure remote systems. This includes:

- Getting account details and (admin) credentials.
- Generating a user/token/credentials with appropriately bounded permissions for use with Meltano.

For databases I additionally need to:

- Ensure connectivity (network level, VPN,  firewall etc.)
- Configure replication features (to support higher fidelity replication methods)

I would like to be able to run:

```
# Download and install plugin to interact with specific source types
meltano add source aws
# Discover available sources
meltano config aws list
# Add an individual source to the meltano project. Returns a `source_id`.
meltano config aws add <arn>
# Asses the status of a source (the actions listed above)
meltano config aws <source id> describe
# Perform outstanding actions
meltano config aws <source_id> key 'enable_logical_replication'
```

The above commands imply that Connection Manager is built by extending the existing `meltano.yml` or introducing a new `connections.yml` that is checked in to source control. Some thought will have to be given to secrets (much like in the current `meltano.yml`). A secrets backed (e.g. to AWS Parameter Store) might therefore be in scope to ensure secrets can be added by the cli but are not checked in to source control.

This would augment the existing Meltano ELT, allowing you to do:

```
meltano config extractor <extractor name> --source <source_id>
```

## Broader Vision

Configuration Manager would be deployed as a separate service, similar to Airflow and the Meltano UI. It will have its own UI (with separate users to regular ELT pipelines - 'admins'), a facility for managing secrets, receive elevated permissions to configure upstream systems __and__ the bounded permissions for Tap/Target use and be the 'source of truth' representation of resources in remote systems for use in other tools in the ecosystem (Meltano ELT, dbt sources etc.). End users would have a path to only update connection details and credentials, and to check on the status of credentials. Connection Manager could support the scheduled rotation of credentials and could potentially act as a tunnel for connections from Meltano to resources within corporate networks. (see [suggestion here](https://gitlab.com/meltano/meltano/-/issues/2873#note_637562612)).

_decoded_content.title: Explore potential for out-of-box data repository, data lake, and/or SQL interface layer
_decoded_content.description:
While many potential users of Meltano will already be bought into a specific SQL platform, some users likely have not, and some may have other reasons why they would rather start fresh in a new DataOps-friendly ecosystem rather than tying more dependency to their existing/legacy SQL platform.

There are a few options we could explore for serverless or turn-key data platforms which are still modern and scalable.

Meltano currently ships with guidance regarding spinning up a docker-based PostgreSQL database, but it would be potentially valuable to add support for a more modern, scalable, and cloud-friendly option such as [Spark](https://github.com/fishtown-analytics/dbt-spark) (perhaps on Databricks?), [ClickHouse](https://clickhouse.te), or similar. Importantly, we should strive to support at least one turn-key platform which is capable of scaling storage separate from compute, which is not the case with traditional RDBMS systems like PostgreSQL.

Another option would be to provide scripts to setup a new Snowflake environment, assuming users would spin up a 30-day Snowflake trial, which only requires an email address.

_decoded_content.title: Let `meltano ui` also start UIs for Airflow and other plugins
_decoded_content.description:
I imagine that `meltano ui airflow superset` would start Meltano's UI, _and_ invoke `airflow webserver` and `superset run` (https://gitlab.com/meltano/meltano/-/issues/2605). 

This could work with any plugin that defines a `ui` command (https://gitlab.com/meltano/meltano/-/issues/2560), just like `meltano orchestrate` will work with any that defines an `orchestrate` command (https://gitlab.com/meltano/meltano/-/issues/2231).

Since `meltano ui` may need to know (and control) each web server's port to prevent conflicts, plugins may need a setting to set the port and a `ui_port` extra to get it in a consistent fashion.

_decoded_content.title: Add Jupyter as a Meltano plugin
_decoded_content.description:
By adding Jupyter/Jupyterhub as a plugin for Meltano it will be easy to create notebooks for exploratory data analysis. As @DouweM mentioned in the discussion on [this issue](https://gitlab.com/meltano/meltano/-/issues/539#note_512452727), this could tie in with [issue #2546](https://gitlab.com/meltano/meltano/-/issues/2546) by allowing relevant environment variables to be loaded as part of the `invoke` command e.g. `--with: meltano invoke --with=target-postgres jupyter notebook`

It'd be good to get a list of Jupyter-specific configuration which might need to be set up as part of this command. The first one which springs to mind is the database connection setup, which should use the connection parameters specified as part of the loader config.

_decoded_content.title: Explore integration with other "git for data" FOSS tools
_decoded_content.description:
This spreadsheet listing "git for data" FOSS tools in various domains (including Meltano) was [shared by Justin Cormack](https://twitter.com/justincormack/status/1333886430989443077) on Twitter: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1jGQY_wjj7dYVne6toyzmU7Ni0tfm-fUEmdh7Nw_ZH0k/edit#gid=0

We should find out if any of these would make good Meltano plugins (https://meltano.com/docs/plugins.html), like we already have Singer integration (https://meltano.com/docs/integration.html), dbt transformation (https://meltano.com/docs/transforms.html) and Airflow orchestration (https://meltano.com/docs/orchestration.html), and support for Great Expectations validation (https://gitlab.com/meltano/meltano/-/issues/2454) and Dagster orchestration (https://gitlab.com/meltano/meltano/-/issues/2393) underway.

_decoded_content.title: Support for a migration plugin type
_decoded_content.description:
Often additional warehouse maintenance tasks need to be handled which don't fall in the scope of a pipeline.  Perhaps a table or schema got renamed, or you explicitly wish to add indexes to a particular column.

Adding a migration plugin such as [Alembic](https://alembic.sqlalchemy.org/en/latest/) would allow Meltano to track database migrations in a source-controlled way, e.g.

```bash
meltano add migrator alembic
meltano invoke alembic revision -m "rename schema"
meltano invoke alembic upgrade
```
